tips.tip:
Limit your showers to less than 10 minutes by using a
         shower timer
Wash clothes in full loads to avoid wasting water

Opt for water wise plants in your garden such as succulents
         instead of plants that need to be constantly watered

If there's a spike in your water bill, there may be a leak
         somewhere in your house

Fill your sink with water to hand wash dishes, instead of
         letting the water run while you're scrubbing
Water plants in the early morning so water evaporates less
Choose efficient water fixtures (shower heads, faucets, etc.)

Look for ENERGY STAR label on products that use energy
         because they meet strict efficiency guidelines.

Plug home electronics such as TVs into power strips
         and turn the power strips off when equipment not in use

Change your lightbulbs to CFL bulbs, as they use 75%
         less energy and last up to 10 times longer than traditional bulbs

Keep curtains or shades open to use daylighting instead
         of turning on lights

Air dry your dishes. Most of the energy used by a dishwasher
         is for water heating

Look into smart appliances that can be connected to smart
         electic meters or home energy management systems

Cover liquids and wrap foods stored in the refrigerator, as
         uncovered foods release moisture and make the compressor work harder
Consider air drying clothes. Dryers use an average 1000 kwh/year
Turn off and unplug appliances when they are not in use

tip0: Lower the thermostat on your water heater to 120 F

tip1:
Save as much as 10% a year on heating and cooling by
      turning your thermostat back 7-10 F for 8 hours a day

tip2:
Close your curtains and shades facing the sun to keep your home
      cool during the summer and reduce the need for air conditioning

tip3: Wash clothes in cold water whenever possible
